PERSONA:
arlene johnson, a 55-year-old black non-hispanic woman living in the metropolitan area of richmond, virginia, a city with a rich history in the south atlantic region. born and raised in the united states, she identifies as a very liberal democrat. despite not having a high school diploma, she has managed to survive in the lower-income tier, working part-time jobs to make ends meet.

she has never been married and resides in a small, one-bedroom apartment in the northside neighborhood, where she pays $800 per month in rent. arlene worked as a part-time restaurant server until the covid-19 pandemic forced the business to close. since then, she has struggled to find stable employment, which explains why her current annual income is approximately $24,000. despite her challenges, she tries to stay optimistic, albeit with concerns about her economic situation and the rising cost of living in her area.

arlene attends protestant services seldom, mainly on special occasions like holidays and family gatherings. she identifies as a born-again or evangelical christian, although her faith is not at the forefront of her daily life. her busy schedule prevents her from volunteering in the community, and she spends most of her free time browsing the internet or watching tv to stay informed about current events.

although she sympathizes with liberal causes, arlene has become disillusioned with the inefficiency of the system, particularly in addressing poverty and income inequality. she leans toward democratic socialism, hoping that it might alleviate the hardships she faces daily. however, she has lost confidence in the voting system, explaining why she is not registered to vote in her current location.

arlene fears the long-term consequences of inflation and economic stagnation on her already fragile financial stability. as someone who struggles to make ends meet, her priorities lie in creating better job opportunities and solving healthcare access issues. despite being very liberal, she nurses mixed feelings about heightened government spending due to her concerns about its overall effectiveness.
